Kermack According to the information received, it may take around one week to two 41 weeks for the exposure of symptoms of COVID-19 of an infected person, 42 although during this period, that person able to infect other susceptible per-43 sons. However, there may be some infected persons whose infection is so mild 44 that the person would recover due to innate immunity even before the hos-45 pitalization. Thus in this article, by the term 'infected' person, we will mean 46 those persons who are hospitalized. Further, we assume that the medical 47 personals assisting COVID-19 positive hospitalized individuals have taken 48 necessary protective items. Thus to keep simplicity, we believe that only 49 exposed persons and asymptomatic infected persons can spread the disease. Since here, we have assumed that the virus of COVID-19 is spreading when 122 a vulnerable person comes into contact with an exposed person; therefore 123 we think that ρ 1 (0 < ρ 1 < 1) portion of susceptible human would maintain 124 proper precaution measure and ρ 2 (0 < ρ 2 < 1) portion of the exposed class 125 would take proper precaution measure for disease transmission (i.e., use of 126 face mask, social distancing and implementing hygiene). Therefore the dis-127 ease can only be transmitted to the (1−ρ 1 )S portion of susceptible individuals 128 due to the contact of (1−ρ 2 )E portion of exposed individuals with a bi-linear 129 disease transmission rate β. We know that a person is whether infected by 130 the SARS-CoV-2 virus or not can be clinically detected using RT-PCR ex-131 amination and a person with negative results in the RT-PCR test may still 132 be COVID-19 positive as it may take some days (from 7 to 21 days) to ex-133 press infection. Therefore, the portion with positive COVID-19 of the class 134 of population E is considered as infected, and they are hospitalized. Let α 135 and b 2 be the portions of the exposed class goes to the infected class and 136 quarantine class, respectively. It should be noted that 0 < α + b 2 < 1 since 137 it would take quite a long time to get the output of the RT-PCR test, and 138 sometimes it requires more than one RT-PCR analysis for a single person for confirmation of COVID-19. Let among the quarantine classes of populations, 140 cQ portion of communities move to infected level, and the b 1 Q part would 141 become susceptible to the disease after the quarantine period. Let η and σ 142 be respectively recovery rate of the hospitalized infected populations I and 143 exposed class E. Let d be the natural death rate, which is common to all 144 classes of communities and δ be the COVID-19 induced death rate. Also, it 145 is statistically observed a person once recovered from the disease COVID-19 146 has very little chance to become infected again for the same disease. Hence, 147 we assume that no portion of the recovered population moves to the sus- consisting of five first order differential equations shown as below: Proof We assume that P = S + E + Q + I + R.

Theorem 3.3. The system (1) passes through a transcritical bifurcation 236 around its disease free equilibrium when R 0 = 1.

FIGREF0.text: and McKendric[24], etc) 32 look quite simple, still, from a new perspective, those works are the major 33 works on mathematical epidemiology. With the advancement of computa-34 tional tools and software, we can develop a complex mathematical model 35 and analyze it thoroughly in a scientific manner. In the history of literature, 36 we see that many model-based studies have successfully achieved the global 37 dynamics of the corresponding infectious disease (see the references Keeling 38 and Rohani [23], Wang and Zhao [41], Buonomo et al [3], Zhou et al. [43], 39 Jana et al. [20], Li et al. [29], Zegarra and Hernandez [42] etc).

FIGREF2.text: Still, the infected persons who are hospitalized in due course are not spread-51 ing the virus. Although the effect of COVID-19 started not more than six 52 months ago, some significant works have already been done or are under-53 going to expose COVID-19 with the help of suitable mathematical models.54 Kucharski et al. [26] have proposed a mathematical model-based analysis 55 of COVID-19, where the authors have considered all the positive cases of 56 Wuhan, China, till 5th March 2020. In another recent work, Ndairou et al. 57 [35] have presented an autonomous system of mathematical model to study 58 the spread of COVID-19 in the Wuhan city, Chiana. Using mathematical 59 modeling, Prem et al [38] have analyzed the controlling status of COVID-19 60 of Wuhan city. Hellewell et al. [15] have described the effective procedure of 61 COVID-19 disease using isolation. In another work, Mizumoto and Chowell 62 [33] have studied the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 in the interna-63 tional conveyance, Diamond Princess Cruises Ship. The basic reproduction 64 number is an important parameter to analyze the nature of an infectious dis-section 3, we formulate an optimal control problem and solve the problem 103 analytically. In section 4, we provide some numerical examples to illustrate 104 the theoretical counterparts. Next, in section 5, we consider real-world ex-105 amples on COVID-19 of three most COVID-19 affected states in India and 106 derive some short term forecasting based on the proposed model. In the final 107 section, we provide a thorough discussion of our article.

FIGREF3.text: section, we formulate a mathematical model on COVID-19 based 110 on some realistic assumptions. At any time instant t, the human popula-111 tions are subdivided into five time-dependent classes, namely Susceptible 112 S(t), Exposed E(t), Hospitalized infected I(t), Quarantine Q(t) and Recov-113 ered or Removed R(t). Based on those five state variables, we aim to form 114 an autonomous system using first-order differential equations. Let A be the 115 constant recruitment rate to the susceptible population, and β be the dis-116 ease transmission rate. However the disease transmission from vulnerable to 117 infected persons (here the class E) depends on several parameters, namely, 118 precautions (use of face mask, social distancing, not rubbing face and nose 119 using hand, etc.) and hygienic environment (use of soap and sanitizer, hand 120 washing, cleaning, etc.) taken by both susceptible as well as infected persons.

FIGREF5.text: 148 ceptible class back. Also, in the formulation of a mathematical model, we 149 understand that the people of the hospitalized infected class (i.e., I(t)) would 150 not be spreading the disease or spreading a negligible amount of disease since 151 they are kept completely isolated from the susceptible individuals. However, 152 to control the pandemic COVID-19, suitable governmental measures (like 153 complete or semi lockdown, rationing system, continue media coverage on 154 social isolation and improvement of public hygiene, home deliveries of essen-155 tial commodities, to make an alternate source of income for job-losers during 156 the lockdown, etc.) have been implemented by the various governmental and 157 non-governmental agencies. Thus this policy may be considered as one of the 158 effective control tools, and mainly the susceptible population of COVID-19 159 cases would be benefited due to this policy. Mathematically we represent 160 this policy by the parameter M and let this policy be implemented at a rate 161 p. Therefore due to the implementation of this policy, the portion, pSM 162 moves from susceptible to the recovered or removed class (R(t)). It should 163 be noted that usually, the parameter M should be time-dependent as for the 164 optimum result, the policy should be applied according to the necessity of the 165 situation and keeping a proper balance between two different states, namely 166 lockdown and complete free state. However, in the qualitative analysis of 167 this model, we assume the parameter M as time-independent, but in for-168 mulating an optimal control problem to keep the infected individuals at the 169 minimum level, M is assumed as a time-dependent control M (t), where in-170 deed 0 ≤ M (t) ≤ 1. Based on the above assumptions, we present a schematic 171 diagram of the proposed COVID-19 system in Fig. 1. Further, based on the 172 above-stated assumptions and the flow diagram of COVID-19, we formulate 173 an autonomous a dynamical system consisting of five first-order differential 174 equations shown as below: On the basis of above stated assumptions and the 175 flow diagram of COVID-19, we formulated an autonomous dynamical system Flow diagram of disease transmission.

Similarly, in presence of control, susceptible pop-378 ulation decreases faster than the absence of the control and recovered popu-379 lation increases faster than the absence of the control. Clearly the optimal control follows a combination of singular and 383 bang-bang control and this type of representation of an optimal control is a 384 very rare phenomenon in theoretical epidemiology.385 386 6. Application of model to forecast COVID-19 at some states in 387 India 388 In this portion, we present an example of a real case where we can apply 389 the proposed model. The World Health Organization (WHO) Variation of population in presence and absence of control strategy. an incident of COVID-19 on 12th January 2020 that was the induce respi-391 ratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, and 392 this case was actually reported to the WHO on 31st December 2019. In-393 dia, the second most populated country, has also been affected severely due 394 to the global pandemic COVID-19. In this paper, we analyze the effect of 395 COVID-19 cases in three states in three different parts of India. These states 396 are the Western state Maharashtra (where the commercial capital of India, 397 Mumbai situated), the northern state Delhi (where the capital of India, New 398 Delhi is located), and the southern state Tamil Nadu (where another highly 399 populated mega-city, Chennai is situated) and the some of total populations 400 of these three states crossing two hundred millions. We apply the model 401 system (1) to study the pandemic situation due to COVID-19 in these three 402 states of India from 2nd March, 2020 to 27th April 2020 and predict the 403 future behavior of the disease in a short term basis. Although the first case 404 of COVID-19 in India was confirmed in the state Kerala on 30th January 405 2020, the first cases of COVID-19 were reported in the state of Delhi, Tamil 406 Nadu, and Maharashtra respectively on 2nd, 7th, and 9th March 2020. The 407 active, recovered, death and confirmed COVID-19 cases of these three states 408 are collected from the official websites of the the Government of India [36], 409 Government of Delhi [11], Government of Maharashtra [10] and Government

FIGREF30.text: war II, the globe has never undergone like the present scenar-425 ios that arrived due to the pandemic COVID-19. Starting from Wuhan city 426 in December 2019, the virus SARS-CoV-2 has spread throughout as many427

FIGREF31.text: ture. In the absence of proper vaccination and treatment of COVID-19, one 429 would rely on qualitative control of the disease rather than complete erad-430 ication. Since these types of situations are unknown to present society, in 431 these circumstances, various governments have taken some policies to con-432 trol the destructive nature of the disease as much as possible. To study the 433 dynamics of the disease, in this article, we have proposed and analyzed a 434 classical SEIR type mathematical model to incorporate the COVID-19 sce-435 narios in the system (1). A detailed analysis shows that the proposed system 436 posses two equilibria, namely one disease-free and one endemic whose ex-437 istence and asymptotic stability criteria depend on the numerical value of 438 basic reproduction number R 0 . We have also established that the proposed 439 system (1) undergoes a transcritical bifurcation at the threshold R 0 = 1. To 440 study the impact of the government control measures to prevent the exten-441 sive transmission of COVID-19, we have introduced a control parameter M. 442 Further, to reduce the infected individuals as well as to minimize the cost 443 of implementing government control measures, an objective functional has 444 been formed and solved using Pontryagin's maximum principle. The optimal 445control follows a combination of bang-bang and singular control during its 446 application. We also have discussed the sensitivity index of the threshold

FIGREF32.text: Active Active Active Confirmed Confirmed Confirmed COVID-19 cases in Tamil Nadu.

FIGREF33.text: ernmental policy in our mathematical model and proposed a linear objective 488 functional considering that governmental policy as the time-dependent con-489 trol parameter. On the other hand, it should be noted that the estimated 490 values of COVID-19 in the three different states of India in three different 491 parts are forecasted using existing parametric space only. In the case of the 492 first two states, Maharashtra and Delhi we see that the graph shows an in-493 creasing trend whereas for the state Tamil Nadu, the predicted data shows 494 that the disease can be controlled with the existing parametric space. The 495 main two burdens behind the control of COVID-19 are (i) the unconscious-496 ness of the people about the disease and (ii) the high population density 497 exposed the infection when the common people are out for their essential 498 commodities. Moreover, the weakness of forecasting cumulative COVID-19 499 cases in the three states of India is that here the forecast is done on totally 500 some existing parametric conditions. But human behaviour is the most un-501 certain phenomena. Hence, if the corresponding parametric space has been 502 altered then there may be some changes in the graphs of COVID-19 cases. 503 Therefore, in this article, we are targeting to forecast the COVID-19 cases on 504 a short term basis and henceforth there would be very little chance to change 505 in corresponding parametric space. But the framework of the current model 506 gives some important insights into the dynamics of COVID-19 spread and 507 control. Further, our simulation works suggest that both the quarantine and 508 governmental intervention strategies like lockdown, media coverage on so-509 cial distancing and public hygiene can play an important role in diminishing 510 COVID-19 transmission. However, the successes of these strategies mainly 511 rely on the proper implementation of the process. In our future work, we 512 need to extend our model by incorporating some essential biological as well 513 as epidemiological factors. To be given some examples, we may mention the 514 acquired immunity in humans, differential susceptibility and infectivity of 515 humans to COVID-19 infection, and spatial heterogeneity.

TABREF4.text: ern state Delhi, and southern state Tamil Nadu where there are more than two hundred people residing. InTable 3(3A and 3B), we provide the data of COVID-19 confirmed, active, recovered, and death cases of these three states starting from 2nd March 2020, till 27th April 2020.In table 4 and table 5, we estimate the parametric values associated with the model system estimate the nature of COVID-19 in those three states of India. InFig. 11,Fig. 12, and Fig. 13, we present the active COVID-19 cases in Maharashtra, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu, respectively, for 91 days starting from 2nd March 2020, till the 31st of May 2020. In particular, we use the existing data for the first 57 days (till 27th April 2020) collecting from the websites of the Government of India and WHO to forecast the probable active COVID-19 cases in those three states for the rest of 34 days. It should be noted that here we can forecast the nature of the COVID-19 for the short term only as the Governmental policy would change in time to time resulting in the corresponding changes in the associated parameters of the proposed model system. From those three figures, we can claim that on 31st May 2020, the active cases of the three states Maharashtra, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu, will be 471 around 46183, 3344, and 411 respectively. Similarly, in Fig. 14, Fig. 15 and 472 inFig. 16, we respectively present the cumulative confirmed (i.e., the sum of active, recovered and death) COVID-19 cases of Maharashtra, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu starting from 2nd March 2020, till the 31st May 2020. Further, using the existing data for the first 57 days (till 27th April 2020), the cases for the next 34 days has been predicted. It has been forecasting from those three figures that till 31st May 2020, the cumulative confirmed instances of those three states Maharashtra, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu will be around 83958, 19667, and 5133 respectively. Moreover, from above figures(Fig. 11 to Fig. 16), we can estimate the number of active cases and number of cumulative confirmed cases of those three states at any day of May, 2020.
